title: Does the human body need carbohydrates? - Quora

response.answer_text: First of all, let me start with stating that our bodies need FAR less carbohydrates than most people think. I mean really, really significantly less than most people think. In fact, you can live more or less normally if you consume ZERO carbohydrates. Your body has a wonderful mechanism to prevent starvation in such case by entering ketosis. Carbs are just a source of energy (and, well, tasty food, most of the time, too, I agree). But your body can utilize other sources to generate ATP (energy currency that supports all biological processes) - it can use fat and even proteins. It’s extremely versatile that way. If you do not consume any carbohydrates (or if you consume far less than would be required to support your energy needs), your body switches to using fat for energy - that can be stored body fat or dietary fat that you consume with food. Your brain (which accounts for about 20% of energy needs) cannot use fat directly (fat cannot cross blood brain barrier), but a byproduct of fat metabolism (ketone bodies) can - and they are actually a cleaner and more efficient substrate for energy production in the brain. The only cells that absolutely must get glucose to get energy through anaerobic glycolysis are red blood cells (they don’t have mitochondria to oxidize fat). But that requirement is quite low compared to your overall energy needs - and it can still be easily satisfied even if you consume zero exogenous carbs (your body can actually turn other substrates into glucose to satisfy that requirement through a process called gluconeogenesis). So you don’t technically need carbohydrates - you can perfectly survive without them. Would I recommend a zero-carb diet? No. And it would be EXTREMELY difficult to achieve, too, because small amount of carbs will be lurking in a lot of food you wouldn’t even suspect. But would I recommend low-carb diet? Absolutely! Anything around 20-40 grams per day (unless you are pregnant) would be just fine. In fact - there are multiple medical benefits of drastically reducing carbs.

The problem is that your brain only runs on glucose. It cannot use fat as a metabolic fuel (your muscles or liver, for example, can run on either). (All dietary sugars are converted into glucose in the gut wall). In situations where there isn't enough glucose (e.g. because you don't eat enough), there is a metabolic process called gluconeogenesis which converts some amino acids into glucose. But it's not terribly effective; it's like driving your car in reverse. You can do it, but it's awkward. In situations of extreme glucose depletion, your brain can run on ketones. For some reason these are called ketone bodies in the literature. Again ketones come from protein breakdown, and again it is very inefficient. In order to get enough protein your body will sacrifice any protein within you to make ketones. This is a starvation situation. Low carb diets are designed to create these two scenarios to some extent. They provide lots of protein for these unusual metabolic processes, but no carbs, which forces you into gluconeogenesis or even ketosis. It seems likely that our human ancestors were used to having periods where food was scarce (e.g. long winters) or when protein (such as animals) was available but carbs (like fruit or grains) wasn't. So some people think it's good for us to mimic these conditions for ourselves. I have some sympathy with this view. "Carbohydrates" also includes indigestible material such as cellulose, which we normally call roughage or dietary fibre. This provides stools with bulk which our colons seem to like. It's not essential I suppose, but it's a helpful part of our diet.

Yes. The brain need glucose to function normally. Glucose is a carbohydrate. If the body stop getting enough glucose, the liver will start releasing stored glucose. And the liver will start synthesizing new glucose by breaking down fat. If the body still don't get glucose after the stores are used, the whole body will start a stress response where every cell is on high alert and the liver, which can't keep up on the glucose production, will start breaking down our muscle mass to make the alternative brain fuel: keton bodies. However keton bodies are not as good as glucose, and after an extended period they can cause a really toxic state. And all through this the body is in high stress mode. The body also have many sugar groups attached to important signals and signal receivers. The body needs glucose to make these sugar components efficiently. So lack of carbohydrates will stress the body, which can lead to hypertension and heart and kidney problems. It has a risk of initiating a toxic state. And it will make body function and regulation less efficient.

If you study nutrition, you’ll find there are essential fatty-acids and there are essential amino acids; they are essential because the human body does not produce them by itself and requires them in order to be healthy. Most vitamins and minerals that have adequate bioavailability come in foods with carbohydrates, whether they are are fibers, starches, or sugars. Foods that do not have carbs can be either meats, or supplements. The problem with eating just meat as a human comes not only from the side of possible cholesterol imbalance, aside from the saturated fat, the Igf-1, endotoxins, inflammation and cancer. Most doctors wouldn’t recommend an all meat diet to a human. In nutrition carbohydrates, proteins and fats are considered to be the the primary macronutrients, suggesting that your body needs several grams of each as opposed to miligrams. Carbohydrates should be included in a diet more rich in antioxidants for protecting the CV system. Carbohydrate sources are often more efficient in terms of labor costs when comparing the price of raising livestock. Supplements, although they appear to be greatly simple in theory, have their own set of problems: including trusting they are what they say they are: I know they aren’t even regulated by the the FDA in the USA. The Exogenous Endotoxin Theory | NutritionFacts.org Dangers of Vitamins and Supplements - Consumer Reports

It does not need carbohydrates but it prefers carbohydrates because they are easier to metabolize. Our body actually prefers to store in the for of lipids, as lipid stores aren't hydrated allowing for lighter energy storage. Our bodies can survive off of fat and proteins by undergoing ketogenesis, in which in incorporates lipids and proteins into the krebs cycle. Besides dietary carbohydrates, carbs are necessary for signaling. There are many glucoconjugates, such as the glycoproteins expressed on cell membranes, that are involved in signaling and recognition. Carbs are also necessary for structural purposes. Polysaccharides are commonly play a structural role, especially in plants in the form of cellulose.

No. There are one or two tissues that only use glucose ( the brain is not one of them), but the liver can turn both fat and muscle into glucose through the process of gluconeogenesis. In the early 1900s, an experiment was done in which two explorers who had lived with Inuits for a while and observed that they did not consume any carbohydrates checked themselves into one of the most prestigious teaching hospitals in New York City, and lived for whole year, under observation, eating only animal products (all edible parts, not just muscle meat) . At the end of the year, they were in better health than when they entered and both lived long, healthy lives.

YES. Yes it does. Don't let anyone tell you otherwise. Sensible explanations from the previous posters will explain why.  Anyone who tries to tell you  "NO, the brain can run on ketones", is kind of a liar. Yes the brain can run on ketones, but its a backup. Not the preferred system. And there are no long term studies to confirm whether ketones are safe to run on.  So, to reiterate, yes the body needs carbs. What it doesn't need is crappy refined/processed carbs. That's a really important difference.

We do need glucose in our blood. We do not need glucose in our diet. None at all. The body burns excess protein grams as fuel. Roughly half of the energy goes through gluconeogenesis synthesizing new glucose. The body burns fat by three pathways. The result is at least 10% of the energy as glucose. Glyercol gets bonded together to make glucose. The slow fatty acid method using acetyl-CoA does not make glucose. The fast fatty acid method produces 3 types of ketones and the acetone part can make glucose by an inefficient method. If you eat zero carb you will eventually be miserable from the effect on cortisol levels. You will eventually stall because T3 release tracks carb intake. You will eventually fall out of ketosis because leptin release tracks carb intake. But you will definitely not die until old age.

No. Humans can thrive on a diet that is virtually free of carbohydrates (except fibre) by adopting a ketogenic diet and putting the body in ketosis ( not to be confused with an illness called ketoacidosis ) In ketosis the body converts fats to what are termed ketone bodies these are small molecules that serve as fuel for all parts of the body (including the brain) if the body needs glucose for particular purposes it is capable of producing it from protein or fat using a process called gluconeogenesis. Ketone bodies - Wikipedia Gluconeogenesis - Wikipedia A low-carb diet for beginners – Diet Doctor

I love these questions as they question something that is at the core of nutrition. Sadly the short answer is: We don't know. Carbohydrates are the most efficient way to power our brain. Though the body has ways to sustain it without the use of carbs directly. Gluconeogenesis or using using ketone bodies or other intermediary molecules. The amount of glucose the brain needs per day is not a lot, as some people will lead you to believe. You'll be fine with 130g per day (roughly 500 kcal). However a comprehensive answer would be way too long for Quora, human metabolism is very complex. Why don't we know the answer? It's quite simple, no one has the resources to basically hire 100 people to eat an all fat and protein diet for a year or longer. And would the answer be worth anything?

We humans function just fine without starchy carbohydrate intake. But, but…“glucose is the preferred energy source of the brain.” Why this sorry sad refrain from those with glucose addled brains? I usually tell a story as it's easier to part the glucose brain fog that way. The human body does what is easiest first. We are a survival machine and in a world without grocery stores, nobody would be having this conversation because you would eat every stick of whatever you could find. Its kinda like asking little Billy if he wants chips or carrot sticks. Of course he prefers chips but carrot sticks are healthier. Just because your body can do the easiest route does not mean its the correct way in our modern world. E-go 2019 rainday

Theoretically, no. The body’s preferred form of energy is glucose (sugar), which complex carbohydrates easily break down into. If no glucose is available, the body can use stored glycogen, or it can turn to fats. However, getting energy from fat is inefficient and can have side effects, and some parts of the body still require glucose. The body can make its own glucose using protein from elsewhere in the body, which keeps glucose-dependent processes running. It’s a lot easier, however, to just eat some carbs. They won’t kill you, I promise.

Key reasons why we need carbohydrates are - Excellent source of energy.Helps preserve muscles. By acting as energy source, carbs makes proteins available for muscle building and maintenance.Promotes digestive health. Complex carbs are rich in dietary fibre hence provides soluble fibre. Soluble fibre is perfect for keeping indigestion at bay, maintain blood cholesterol and glucose levels.Lack of carbs affects our normal metabolism and assures smooth functioning of body processes.Ideal intake of carbs also regulates our mood.Consuming the right carbs is necessary for mental health, and sugar can negatively affect your mood.Carbs are the source of energy for our brain hence lack of carbs might affect brain health as well.Complex carbs also keeps our colon healthy.

Carbohydrates are as need of a human body as protein fats vitamins minerals fibers and water is required along with trace elements and oxygen only how long you can sustain without each is different . So carbohydrates protein and fats are considered as macro nutrients and vitamins minerals trace elements are considered micro nutrients in comparison of their quantity in daily diet not as per important wise. So ideal composition of macro nutrients for general good is 40% carbohydrates 35% proteins and 25% fats .

Carbs are the preferred energy source when abundant as the body lacks any way to store them in significant quantities. They are used to power your muscles and organs like the brain. Excess carbs are turned into body fat via the insulin response. In a low carb environment, the body will adjust to use fat instead and there’s sometimes a period of adjustment known as “low carb flu”. From what i’ve read, the brain has a minimum of about 25 grams requirement of glucose, the rest can come from ketones derived from fats. Textbook of Guyton

Sugars are need to produce ATP, the energy molecule. When blood sugar is low, the stress systems will be activated to compensate for it. T3, the most active thyroid hormone, increases longevity, improves sleep quality, increases metabolism, slows aging, prevents and cures cancers, reduces estrogen, accelerates cholesterol metabolism (thus preventing high blood cholesterol), cures autoimmune disease, such as gluten sensitivity, cures degenerative diseases, reduces the stress hormones, increases brain formation (even in adulthood), etc. The amount of T3 depends on the amount of sugar available, as well as salt, proteins, and saturated fats. Source: raypeat.com/articles/

The human body does not require white sugar granuals that come in a yellow paper package. Humans do require a range of fruits and vegeta bles (carbohydrates) that include all of the essential nutrients needed for human health. Beans, seeds and nuts are protein containing vegetables that belong in every human’s diet.

Yes. Carbohydrates are the main supplier of energy to the body. There are two types of carbohydrates: simple (which can be found in fruits and vegetables, as well as milk and milk products) and complex (which can be found in whole grain breads and cereals, starchy vegetables, and foods with fiber).

Yes, while carbohydrates, fats, and proteins can all be used as an every source, carbohydrates, in the form of glucose, is the preferred energy source. Cells differ with their preference for glucose; some cells, such as neuronal cells, are so dependent upon glucose that glucose can said to be essential.
Yes, we need carbohydrates in our bodies, but we don’t need them in our diet. Our bodies can make them from amino acids and the glycerol backbone of fats.
Yes it does. Your body metabolizes carbs into glucose. The brain is not the only thing that requires glucose to function. Every, single cell in your body needs glucose! Every, single cell!

Carbohydrates, fat and protein all provide energy, but exercising muscles rely on carbohydrates as their main source of fuel. However, muscles have limited carbohydrates stores (glycogen) and they need to be topped up regularly to keep your energy up.

what happens when you try to turn on your car engine but there is no petrol? obviously it does not kick. Similarly if you dont eat well your does not have the energy to work. this energy comes from carbohydrates. the mitochondria of ur cells breakdown this carbohydrate into glucose which is later used as energy. so to summarize, carbohydrate is like a fuel for our body

In addition to the other response, carbohydrates are broken down into glucose which is what your brain uses. While the rest of your body uses proteins, you liver has to convert other molecules into glucose. So lacking too much carbohydrates will cause your brain functioning to deteriorate.
Yes.
